[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary (e.g., "fourpence-halfpenny," "Mæcenas") and formal tone may hinder modern readability.
[SYNTAX]: Complex, lengthy sentence structures (e.g., "It does not follow...") occasionally disrupt flow.

[STRUCTURE]: Transitions between anecdotes (e.g., from "chairman" to "Colonial squatter") lack explicit connectors.
[CLARITY]: Some paragraphs (e.g., discussion of _John Inglesant_) assume reader familiarity with referenced works.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, lengthy sentence structures may impede immediate readability.
[LEXICON]: Archaisms (e.g., "roxburghe calf") and formal tone require contextual familiarity.

[STRUCTURE]: Minor thematic shifts (e.g., abrupt transitions between specific authorial examples) slightly disrupt flow.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally overly complex sentence structures (e.g., lengthy descriptive passages).
[LEXICON]: Archaic phrasing (e.g., "one would rather," "it is amazing that") may slightly impede modern readability.
[TENSE]: Mild inconsistencies in tense shifts (e.g., "were and are").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between book examples (e.g., Balzac to annual reading ritual).
[TRANSITION]: Weak links between paragraphs (e.g., heroine comparison feels tangential).
[LOGIC]: Minor thematic leaps (e.g., shifting from nostalgia to critical analysis).

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, winding sentence structures (e.g., "Because of the mischief...") may impede smooth reading.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between literary analysis (e.g., Jeanie Deans), bookman anecdotes, and historical collector examples.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., lengthy compound sentences).

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift between anecdotes (e.g., Quaritch insertion).
[STRUCTURE]: Mild meandering in thematic connections (e.g., dipsomania analogy).

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, lengthy sentence structures (e.g., "He has also anodynes for his conscience...") that impede smooth reading.
[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary/phrasing (e.g., "to-morrow," "fellow") that may distract modern readers.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between ideas (e.g., from self-justification to Emerson’s room anecdote) without clear connective tissue.
[STRUCTURE]: Repetitive thematic reinforcement (e.g., "his friends... will never play him false") without escalating depth.
